responses.rationale: Contains vivid language ('pry its way') likely triggering an earlier Alarmist rule.
Factual statement about virus characteristics ('change very quickly') without explicit framing cues.
Factual statements about virus characteristics ('change very quickly', 'spread very easily') without explicit framing cues.
Factual description of immunological difference ('look pretty different') without explicit framing cues.
Contains loaded adjective ('sobering findings') likely triggering an earlier Alarmist rule.
Factual report of mild cases and potential ('possible that there will be serious illnesses') without explicit framing cues.
Factual report of case count and outcome spectrum ('wide spectrum of severity') without explicit framing cues.
Factual statement about a potential factor influencing severity without explicit framing cues.
Reports concerns factually ('concerns that it might be difficult') and background condition ('break heat records').
Factual statement about a potential factor influencing severity without explicit framing cues.
Factual description of exposure level and potential outcome ('could lead to severe disease') without explicit framing cues.
Factual statement about virus capability ('able to infect') without explicit framing cues.
Factual statement about agreement without explicit framing cues.
Contains loaded metaphor ('top of the list in terms of bad guy viruses') likely triggering an earlier Alarmist rule.
Factual description of symptoms ('strangely or aggressively') without explicit framing cues.
Factual report of outcome ('all of them died') without explicit framing cues.
Factual report of outcome ('survived, but they ultimately went blind') without explicit framing cues.
Reports public reaction ('on edge') and background condition ('on the rise') factually.
Factual statement about a consequence of precautions without explicit framing cues.
Reports standard procedure ('watching closely') and factual event ('first reported case').
Factual statement about a prevention goal without explicit framing cues.
Factual statement about a person's role without explicit framing cues.
Factual statement about a ranking unrelated to the threat's impact.
Factual statements about potential ('could very easily') and lack of preparedness ('donâ€™t know how to deal with it').
Factual statement about a company's status without explicit framing cues.
Factual report of relative impact ('hardest hit states') without explicit framing cues.
Factual report of consequence ('must be killed') and state of affairs ('uncertainty remains').
Contains loaded adjective ('devastating') likely triggering an earlier Alarmist rule.
Factual statement about transmission vector without explicit framing cues.
Reports standard phrase ('err on the side of caution') without explicit framing cues.
Factual report of an event ('first confirmed case') without explicit framing cues.
Factual report of scale ('Most states have reported cases') without explicit framing cues.
Factual report of event and diagnosis ('sick', 'dead', 'had Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza').
Factual statement about expected trend ('expected to rise') without explicit framing cues.
Factual description of host range and geographic spread without explicit framing cues.
Factual report of outcome ('turned out to be mild') without explicit framing cues.
Factual report of location of cases without explicit framing cues.
Factual description of transmission mechanism without explicit framing cues.
Evaluative comment ('ironic') and factual statement about links to other diseases.
Factual report of CDC action ('stressed the importance') and event ('confirmed human infection').
Factual description of potential symptoms ('can also cause', 'serious symptoms') without explicit framing cues.
Reports public reaction ('expressed concerns') and factual event ('discovery of the first known H5N1 cases').
Factual report of event ('detected its first outbreak', 'confirmation of a case') without explicit framing cues.
Factual report of trend ('increase in the number') and public reaction ('source of concern').
Factual statement about something needing to be dealt with ('to contend with').
Uses metaphor ('Swiss Army Knife') and describes capability ('break into') and factual impact ('infected and killed millions').
Contains vivid descriptor ('voraciousness') and loaded classification ('global zoonotic animal pandemic') likely triggering Alarmist.
Contains loaded metaphor ('collateral damage') likely triggering an earlier Alarmist rule.
Contains intensifier + negative outcome ('major problem') likely triggering an earlier Alarmist rule.
Factual statement about experience and observation without explicit framing cues.
Factual descriptions of symptoms ('stumbling and uncoordinated', 'seizures started') without explicit framing cues.
Contains vivid description of symptoms ('Screaming very loud, whole-body tremors') likely triggering Alarmist.
Factual description of trend ('growing list') and outcome ('could succumb') without explicit framing cues.
Contains intensifier + loaded descriptor ('very sad thing to see') likely triggering Alarmist.
Uses technical/descriptive term ('dead-end infections') without explicit framing cues.
Factual descriptions of conditions ('large amount', 'immune system is too weak') without explicit framing cues.
Factual report of an event/exposure route without explicit framing cues.
Expresses possibility ('could change') and uses idiom for speed ('in the rub of an eye or a small cough').
